column2: forming the southwestern anchor of the Inland Empire region
column3: is approximately 58 miles (93 km) north of downtown San Diego and 85 miles (137 km) southeast of downtown Los Angeles. Temecula is bordered by the city of Murrieta to the north and the Pechanga Indian Reservation and San Diego County to the south. Temecula had a population of 100

column1: The area was inhabited by the Temecula Indians for hundreds of years before their contact with the Spanish missionaries (the people are now generally known as the Luiseños
column2: after the nearby Mission San Luis Rey de Francia). The Pechanga Band of Luiseño believe their ancestors have lived in the Temecula area for more than 10
column4: though ethnologists think they arrived at a more recent date. In Pechanga history
column5: life on Earth began in the Temecula Valley. They call it "Exva Temeeku"
column6: the place of the union of Sky-father
column7: and Earth-mother ("Tuukumit'pi Tamaayowit"). The Temecula Indians ("Temeekuyam") lived at "Temeekunga"
column8: or "the place of the sun". Other popular interpretations of the name include "The sun that shines through the mist" or "Where the sun breaks through the mist".The first recorded Spanish visit occurred in October 1797
column9: with a Franciscan padre
column11: and Captain Pedro Lisalde. Father Santiago kept a journal in which he noted seeing "Temecula ... an Indian village". The trip included Lake Elsinore area and the Temecula Valley.

column2: Spanish Missionaries established the Mission of San Luis Rey de Francia and designated the Indians living in the region as "Sanluiseños"
column4: the nearby Mission San Antonio de Pala was built.

column1: The Mexican land grants made in the Temecula area were Rancho Temecula
column2: granted to Felix Valdez
column3: and to the east Rancho Pauba
column4: granted to Vicente Moraga in 1844. Rancho Little Temecula was made in 1845 to Luiseño Pablo Apis
column5: one of the few former mission converts to be given a land grant. It was fertile well watered land at the southern end of the valley
column6: which included the village of Temecula. A fourth grant
column7: known as Rancho Santa Rosa was made to Juan Moreno in 1846
column8: and was in the hills to the west of Temecula.

column1: As American settlers moved into the area after the war
column2: conflict with the native tribes increased. A treaty was signed in the Magee Store in Temecula in 1852
column3: but was never ratified by the United States Senate. In addition
column4: the Luiseños challenged the Mexican land grant claims
column6: the land was held in trust to be distributed to the local Indian tribes after becoming subjects. They challenged the Apis claim to the Little Temecula Rancho by taking the case to the 1851 California Land Commission. On November 15
column8: the commission rejected the Luiseño claim; an appeal in 1856 to the district court was found to be in favor of the heirs of Pablo Apis (he had died in late 1853 or early 1854). The Luiseño of Temecula village remained on the south side of Temecula Creek when the Apis grant was acquired by Louis Wolf in 1872; they were evicted in 1875.A stagecoach line started a local route from Warner Ranch to Colton in 1857 that passed through the Temecula Valley. column10: with a route between St. Louis

column15: the first inland Southern California post office was established in Temecula in the Magee Store. This was the second post office in the state
column16: the first being located in San Francisco. The Temecula post office was moved in the ensuing years; its present locations are the seventh and eighth sites occupied. The American Civil War put an end to the Butterfield Overland Stage Service
column17: but stage service continued on the route under other stage companies until the railroad reached Fort Yuma in 1877.In 1862

column4: the Vail family built a dam to catch the Temecula Creek water and created Vail Lake. Through the mid-1960s
column5: the economy of the Temecula Valley centered around the Vail Ranch; the cattle business and agriculture were the stimuli for most business ventures. In 1964

column4: drawn by the affordable housing prices and the popular wine country. On October 27

column9: 000. After a period of rapid population growth and home construction
column10: the 2007 subprime mortgage financial crisis and the resultant United States housing market correction caused a sharp rise in home foreclosures in the Temecula-Murrieta region.

column1: According to the United States Census Bureau

column3: of which 37.27 square miles (96.5 km2) of it is land and 0.012 square miles (0.031 km2) of it (0.03%) is water. South of the city

column1: Temecula has a warm Mediterranean climate (Köppen:Csa). August is typically the hottest month of the year with December being the coldest month. Most precipitation occurs from November to March with February being the wettest month. Winter storms generally bring moderate precipitation
column2: but strong winter storms are not uncommon especially during "El Niño" years. The driest month is June. Annual precipitation is 14.14 inches. Morning marine layer is common during May and June. From July to September
column4: dry weather with the occasional North American monsoonal flow that increases the humidity and brings isolated thunderstorms. Most of the storms tend to be short-lived with little rainfall. During late fall into winter
column6: windy northeastern Santa Ana winds. Snowfall is rare
column7: but Temecula has experienced traces of snowfall on occasion
column8: some as recently as December 2014. A rare F1 tornado touched down in a Temecula neighborhood on February 19

column1: The French Valley Airport is located in the Temecula Valley. Temecula is also located within 60 miles (97 km) of both the Ontario International Airport and the San Diego International Airport.
The Temecula Cemetery is operated by the Temecula Public Cemetery District. Land for the cemetery was originally donated by Mercedes Pujol in 1884 from the estate of her husband
column2: Domingo Pujol.

Temecula provides police service in cooperation with the Riverside County Sheriff's Department via a contract with the department fulfilled through its Southwest Sheriff's Station
column2: located in the unincorporated community of French Valley
column3: just north of the city of Temecula
column4: east of State Route 79 (Winchester Road). The station is adjacent to the Riverside County Superior Court's Southwest Regional Judicial District Courthouse and Southwest Detention Center
column5: one of the five regional jails in Riverside County. The sheriff's station is currently commanded by Captain Lisa McConnell
column6: who also serves as Temecula's Chief of Police.

column1: The city of Temecula contracts for fire and paramedic services with the Riverside County Fire Department through a cooperative agreement with CAL FIRE. Temecula currently has five fire stations with five paramedic engine companies
column2: one truck company and two CAL FIRE wildland fire engines.American Medical Response provides paramedic ambulance transport to an emergency department.

column1: Leidschendam-Voorburg (Netherlands; 1993-2019)Temecula maintains international relations with Daisen
column2: Tottori in Japan. Until 2019

column1: The Temecula Duck Pond is also home to an art piece entitled "Singing in the Rain". It was commissioned by the city of Leidschendam-Voorburg as a gift to the city to commemorate the resilient American spirit in the aftermath of the September 11 attacks. The piece depicts a mother and her children bravely pedaling a bicycle into the strong headwinds of a storm.
